comment._content:

Whiteinch, Scotland

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48761017@N07] This link has a good picture of the ferry FAIRLIGHT. The book 'Manly Ferries of Sydney Harbour' by Tom Mead also has some good info on the vessel, describes it as 'quite a popular vessel until 1908'. Seems the ferry was involved in a bad accident two days before Christmas in 1882, running down a sailing boat near Middle Head and killing one man.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The 'Fairlight' originally had sails too! - see illustration p.51 of Andrews' 'History of Sydney Ferries'. Earlier photo by Henry King (in front of Admiralty House without its second storey) - from.ph/30882 Mega-zoomable I love all the people on this ferry. They look like they are off to Manly to have a Really Great Day Out, dressed up to the nines. I reckon early to mid 1890s (due to the undeveloped state of Garden Island). What does the fashion expert think?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good morning! Our fashion expert thinks late 1890s to early 1900s, some of the hemlines look as though they are not reaching the ground which indicates a later date. They all look very dapper, I wonder what event they were off to?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] A thought - this has to be before 1893 as the enormous sheerlegs crane on Garden Island is not evident in this photo.  It would stick right up (see note). Sometimes it is easier to date photos by something which isn't there - see comments etc - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs/6917987866/]

comment.author: 65669741@N08
comment._content: She was fitted with sails for the journey out - but didn't have them as a permanent fixture.
